<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```typescript
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```
}

<<<explanation>>>: The code provided is a Java implementation of a StringTokenizer that allows for more control over how tokens are handled. The `getStringTokenizerStrict` method creates a new StringTokenizer with the given delimiter and a flag indicating whether to include NULL tokens. The `altStringTokenizer` method demonstrates how to use the `StringTokenizer` to extract tokens from a string.

To validate multiple comma-separated email addresses in Android, you can use a regular expression to match against a pattern that matches common email formats. Here is an example of how you can do this:
```java
static boolean validEmail(String str_newEmail) {
    return str_newEmail.matches("^[_A-Za-z0-9-\\+]+(\\.[_A-Za-z0-9-]+)*@" + "[A-Za-z0-9-]+(\\.[A-Za-z0-9]+)*(\\.[A-Za-z]{2,})$");
}
```
This regular expression matches against email addresses that have the following format:

* The local part (before the "@" symbol) can contain any combination of letters, digits, and the following characters: `_` (underscore), `-` (hyphen), `+` (plus sign), and `.` (period).
* The "@" symbol must be present.
* The domain part (after the "@" symbol) can contain any combination of letters, digits, and the following characters: `_` (underscore), `-` (hyphen), and `.` (period).
* The domain part must end with a top-level domain (TLD) that has at least two characters.

You can use this regular expression to validate email addresses in your Android application by calling the `validEmail` method and passing in the email address to be validated.
